a: AIDS (Acquired Immuno Deficiency Syndrome) weakens the immune system, making the body vulnerable to infections. Two common symptoms are \textbf{prolonged fever and chronic diarrhea}, often accompanied by significant weight loss. Patients also frequently suffer from opportunistic infections like pneumonia or tuberculosis.

q: What do you understand by the term 'pathogen'?
a: A pathogen is any disease-causing microorganism, such as a bacterium, virus, fungus, or protozoan. These organisms are capable of invading a host and causing an infection or disease by disrupting normal physiological processes. Examples include \textit{Salmonella typhi} which causes typhoid and \textit{Plasmodium} which causes malaria.

Innate immunity is the non-specific, inborn defense mechanism of the body. It is the first line of defense against invading pathogens and is present from birth. It consists of four types of barriers: \textbf{physical barriers} (like skin), \textbf{physiological barriers} (like stomach acid), \textbf{cellular barriers} (like phagocytes), and \textbf{cytokine barriers} (like interferons).

q: Write about the role of lymphocytes in immunity.
a: Lymphocytes are crucial for acquired immunity. There are two main types: \textbf{B-lymphocytes} and \textbf{T-lymphocytes}. B-lymphocytes produce \textbf{antibodies} to fight pathogens (humoral immunity). T-lymphocytes are responsible for \textbf{cell-mediated immunity}; helper T-cells activate other immune cells, while cytotoxic T-cells directly kill infected cells.

An \textbf{antigen} is any foreign substance, such as a part of a virus or bacterium, that enters the body and triggers an immune response. An \textbf{antibody} is a Y-shaped protein produced by B-lymphocytes in response to a specific antigen. Antibodies bind to antigens and help neutralize or eliminate them from the body.

Vaccination is the process of administering a preparation of weakened or inactivated pathogens, or their antigens (a vaccine), into the body. This stimulates the immune system to produce memory B and T-cells without causing the actual disease, thereby providing \textbf{active acquired immunity} against future infections by that specific pathogen.

q: How are malaria and pneumonia transmitted?
a: \textbf{Malaria} is a vector-borne disease transmitted through the bite of an infected female \textit{Anopheles} mosquito, which injects the \textit{Plasmodium} parasite into the human bloodstream. \textbf{Pneumonia} is primarily transmitted through inhaling respiratory droplets or aerosols released by an infected person when they cough or sneeze.

q: Describe the causative organism, mode of transmission, symptoms and therapy of malaria disease.
a: Malaria is caused by a protozoan parasite of the genus \textbf{\textit{Plasmodium}}. It is transmitted to humans through the bite of an infected female \textit{Anopheles} mosquito. Symptoms include recurring cycles of high fever, chills, and sweating. Therapy primarily involves the use of \textbf{antimalarial drugs} like quinine and chloroquine to kill the parasite in the bloodstream.

q: Write the cause, causative organism and symptoms of typhoid fever.
a: Typhoid fever is a bacterial infection caused by \textbf{\textit{Salmonella typhi}}. The cause of infection is the ingestion of contaminated food and water. Its primary symptoms include sustained high fever, weakness, stomach pain, headache, and loss of appetite. In severe cases, intestinal perforation may occur. The disease is confirmed by the \textbf{Widal test}.

q: What are allergies? Describe its symptoms in brief.
a: An allergy is an exaggerated or hypersensitive response of the immune system to certain environmental substances called allergens, such as pollen or dust. This response is mediated by \textbf{IgE antibodies} and involves the release of chemicals like histamine. Symptoms can range from sneezing, watery eyes, and a runny nose to skin rashes and difficulty breathing.

Cancer is characterized by uncontrolled cell growth, and its symptoms can be varied. Two common warning signs are the presence of a persistent \textbf{lump or thickening} in any part of the body, such as the breast, and a \textbf{change in bowel or bladder habits} that is unexplained and persistent.

Chronic and excessive alcohol consumption has severe ill-effects on the body. It can cause significant damage to the \textbf{liver}, leading to conditions like fatty liver, alcoholic hepatitis, and cirrhosis. It also adversely affects the central nervous system, impairing judgment and coordination, and can lead to dependence, social problems, and damage to the heart and stomach.

Cannabinoids are a group of chemical compounds that interact with cannabinoid receptors in the brain. They are naturally obtained from the inflorescences of the plant \textbf{\textit{Cannabis sativa}}. Products like marijuana, hashish, and charas are derived from this plant and are known to affect the cardiovascular system and produce hallucinogenic effects.

q: What is cocaine? From which plant it is obtained?
a: Cocaine is a powerful central nervous system stimulant that interferes with the transport of the neurotransmitter dopamine, producing a sense of euphoria. It is obtained from the leaves of the \textbf{coca plant} (\textit{Erythroxylum coca}), which is native to South America. It is a potent and addictive drug.

Cell-mediated immunity (CMI) is an immune response that does not involve antibodies. It is primarily mediated by \textbf{T-lymphocytes}. This arm of the immune system is crucial for defending against intracellular pathogens like viruses and bacteria, and is also responsible for killing cancerous cells and for the rejection of transplanted organs.

Active immunity is the immunity that develops in an individual when their own immune system produces antibodies in response to an infection or vaccination. This type of immunity is long-lasting and creates an immunological memory. For example, recovering from chickenpox provides long-term active immunity against the disease.

q: Name the primary and secondary lymphoid organs.
a: Lymphoid organs are where lymphocytes originate, mature, and proliferate. The \textbf{primary lymphoid organs} are the \textbf{bone marrow} and the \textbf{thymus}, where immature lymphocytes differentiate into antigen-sensitive lymphocytes. The \textbf{secondary lymphoid organs} include the \textbf{spleen, lymph nodes, tonsils}, and Peyer's patches, where lymphocytes interact with antigens.

Oncogenesis is the process by which normal cells are transformed into cancerous cells. It is a multi-step process involving genetic and epigenetic changes that disrupt the normal regulation of the cell cycle, leading to uncontrolled cell division and proliferation. This transformation is often triggered by carcinogens or mutations in key regulatory genes like \textbf{oncogenes}.

Metastasis is the most feared property of malignant tumors. It is the process by which cancer cells break away from the primary tumor, travel through the blood or lymph system, and form new, secondary tumors in other parts of the body. This spread of cancer makes it much more difficult to treat.

q: Differentiate between active and passive immunity.
a: \textbf{Active immunity} is produced by an individual's own immune system in response to an antigen (from infection or vaccination); it is slow to develop but long-lasting. \textbf{Passive immunity} is acquired when pre-formed antibodies are transferred from one individual to another (e.g., from mother to fetus); it provides immediate protection but is short-lived.
